text: Metiendo mi cuchara, ayer estaba hablando con unos programadores, ellos con vuejs, y yo con xbase, le comentaba que con modharbour, vamos a tener acceso directo a los dispositivos fisicos como impresoras, un ejemplo seria desde el cliente se captura una compra y se envía al servidor, y el servidor imprime directamente a una impresora conectada en el servidor; Esto bajo el esquema que tengo actualmente en mi tabajo de farmacias, donde hay tres cuatro computadoras punto de venta, y una de estas sirve como servidor; y me interesa quitar todas las impresoras de tickets y solo dejar una ( Claro en el servidor ), las farmacias son pequeñas no son grandes como para que el empleado no pueda tomar el ticket de un solo lugar.

I think a lot of the xBase programmers don't program in OOP. Maybe we can also do a simple syntax like the ch files in clipper / xbase / fivewin for the web.

Possibly because it is so easy to create a program.

text:
I am one of the few here where the children are involved in programming.
I have a program that has been successfully in use for 25 years and we have a large number of customers.
Even if we want, you cannot switch to another programming environment in a short time. And that's why mod harbour is a stroke of luck.
There is also nothing better for small companies than Harbour. Everything is manageable and there are simple solutions for everything.

elements.text:
I am one of the few here where the children are involved in programming.
I have a program that has been successfully in use for 25 years and we have a large number of customers.
Even if we want, you cannot switch to another programming environment in a short time. And that's why mod harbour is a stroke of luck.
There is also nothing better for small companies than Harbour. Everything is manageable and there are simple solutions for everything.

text: I realize that the cost of switching languages or environments is huge, and rewriting everything from scratch doesn't pay off at all. But rewriting bits and pieces in different languages/environments might work, depending on how you approach it.

elements.text: I realize that the cost of switching languages or environments is huge, and rewriting everything from scratch doesn't pay off at all. But rewriting bits and pieces in different languages/environments might work, depending on how you approach it.

text: Not saying you should.

elements.text: Not saying you should.

Andreu, necesitamos un firewall propio para mod

text: Andreu, as a small company, you can only survive if you have a compact programming environment such as Harbour and Fivewin.

elements.text: Andreu, as a small company, you can only survive if you have a compact programming environment such as Harbour and Fivewin.

text: That's the reason the BIG ONES have been buying and destroying EVERY compact programming environment in the market. Their target is Big Dev Teams. They don't want an accountant or shop owner to make his own software tools.

elements.text: That's the reason the BIG ONES have been buying and destroying EVERY compact programming environment in the market. Their target is Big Dev Teams. They don't want an accountant or shop owner to make his own software tools.

text: I'm a bit confused on what you mean by compact, there's a lot of ways to make tools.

elements.text: I'm a bit confused on what you mean by compact, there's a lot of ways to make tools.

text: Is there any reason to have only ONE languaje (js) for ALL browsers ?? They could've made an api to access de DOM and let de user pick it's own languaje. This is an anunnaki conspiration!

elements.text: Is there any reason to have only ONE languaje (js) for ALL browsers ?? They could've made an api to access de DOM and let de user pick it's own languaje. This is an anunnaki conspiration!

text:
In <http://vb.net|vb.net> I used over 80 components from 3rd party providers.
There is always a company who makes something "more beautiful".
But you can no longer manage this and with the next update of the actual language you have to update all components.

elements.text: In
vb.net

I used over 80 components from 3rd party providers.
There is always a company who makes something "more beautiful".
But you can no longer manage this and with the next update of the actual language you have to update all components.

text: A bytecode format, like wasm, would work, and we see the web evolving in that direction. A language wouldn't because every browser would need to support every language.

elements.text: A bytecode format, like wasm, would work, and we see the web evolving in that direction. A language wouldn't because every browser would need to support every language.

elements.text: I'm off. Ping me if you need me.

text:
What I don't like about the other languages is that you can see so much source code.
xBase syntax is simply easier to read for me and you can then concentrate on the actual problems. Programming should only be a tool to solve the problems.

text:
After all this experience, I'm now also unsure which components to use now in future with mod harbour..
I have already chosen bootstrap and I also use dayPilot for the online planner.
For a few days I have been thinking about opting for Material Design for Bootstrap as a UI kit.
